text: Table discussion before lunch.
So if you're feeling a little hungry, I promise we won't starve you.
We are going to talk for the first time in this conference specifically about the relationship
between science, art, and society.
So we added this subject in because we've been talking a lot about specific examples
in education, in collaborative working groups, et cetera.
But there's this larger issue which encompasses everything that we're talking about.
And that's the multi-directional relationship between science and art, art and society,
and science and society.
And my argument, and I'm happy to hear otherwise, is that all of those relationships are damaged
or dysfunctional.
And so what can we do to solve that and to build upon the relationships that we envision
to kind of go towards the future that we envision for ourselves?
So I will let Zach introduce the panelists.
All right, so participants, if you could raise your hand as I call your name.
Eric Hull is a postdoctoral researcher at Columbia University and a writer whose works
have appeared in the Atlantic, American Fiction, and other publications.
Seeing us again, Alana Quinn, Alana is an exhibit and program organizer at the Cultural
Program at the National Academy of Sciences.
Ben Lilly, Ben Lilly is a high energy particle physicist and co-founder and director of the
story collider as well as a contributing editor for TED.com.
He has founded a space called Kaviat, an intellectual events venue.
David Grinspoon is an astrobiologist, award-winning science communicator, and prize-winning author,
as well as an advisor to NASA on space exploration strategy.
Elizabeth Demore.
Elizabeth is a fine artist working in sculpture, digital media, and e-Go art to explore the
interface between the built and natural environments.
Stuart Feierstein.
Stuart is a professor and former chair of the biology department at Columbia University
where he studies vertebrate olfaction, as well as an author and advisor for the public
understanding of science to the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation.
With that, let's start the roundtable.
Ben Lilly.
So something that occurs to me is that this conversation wouldn't have felt as necessary
a few decades ago.
One of the reasons why is that historically, of course, artists and scientists have been
very separate, there was a very important book called The Two Cultures by C.P. Snow about
exactly how separate they are.
But I feel that something kind of important began to happen in the 60s and 70s, which
is that the public profile of science began to grow and moved out of just being something
academic.
And for instance, there are now science accounts on Twitter with millions of followers.
And that simply did not exist prior to science popularization.
The New York Times has a science section of its website.
It didn't use to.
So I think a lot of this is that science as a cultural institution, if Martians came
to our planet and they were sociologists and they asked, what are some of the growing
really important driving institutions to our culture, they would very quickly hit upon
science, this collection of individuals and institutions and the ideas it's producing.
And notice that it's been growing in relevancy.
And I think at this point it's grown to such a degree that it's kind of colliding with
art and all these other things that suddenly people are realizing, well, they not only
have to deal with this, they have to come to some sort of understanding, whether it be
of criticism, whether it be of support or whatever, but they have to do this.
And so I just want to remark that what I see a lot of here is basically this kind of new
error of collision because quite simply science has gotten so big and so important that art
just has to deal with it.
So I just wanted to chime in on that.
So I do art and science collaboration, I'm a sculptor, but I'm a professor at Rutgers.
And I teach in the engineering department and the computer science department in addition
to the art department.
And one of the interesting things I think about this sort of moment is that in so many
different ways in genomic engineering, in AI, computer science, scientists, you know,
once upon a time there was this idea of like the pure science says, right, you'd go and
you'd study the natural world.
And now even the quote unquote pure sciences are making the things that they're studying.
So it's become sort of an applied practice.
And in many ways I see similar kinds of activities happening in the science department that you'd
see over in the art department.
In other words, researchers are making the things that they're studying and then they're
looking at sort of the emergent properties that are coming from it.
So I think that that might also be sort of one of those other kinds of bridges that we're
sort of seeing right now.
It's interesting that I agree with everything you guys both just said that the historical
perspective on the two cultures, this division.
Of course, if you go back farther in history, there was no such division.
Science didn't exist as a separate professional endeavor more than say 150 years ago, give
or take.
Certainly more than 400 years ago, that was a no such thing.
Science was a branch of philosophy, it was natural philosophy, so it was a part of the
humanity.
So this professionalization, this splintering of our professional communities out of the
specialization of knowledge, you know, it's easy to get down on that.
In some sense that it's also been very necessary, we wouldn't have been able to learn and achieve
a lot of what we have without that specialization.
But then we've lost a lot too in our ability to reconnect.
And I think in a way the same thing is true of art.
Art has become a very professionalized endeavor, certainly fine arts.
And that leads to some problems too.
A word that hasn't come up, I don't think explicitly this weekend yet, but I think it
has been implicit a lot in our discussions is elitism.
And I think both art and science have a problem, have an elitism problem.
And it hinders our ability to do in both areas what we feel we want to do, which is
connect, foster wider connections.
And I think the good news is that the kinds of collaborations we've been hearing about
and talking about can really help.
Both art and science can be helped with their elitism problems by working with one another.
And I've experienced this somewhat in my collaborations.
I primarily identify as a scientist, although I have been involved in a lot of collaborations
with artists and I'm also performing musicians, so I get my art kick that way as well.
And I found that one of the many values of these kinds of collaborations is they get
us, and I mean us, collectively artists and scientists, out of our normal boxes and force
us to extend beyond our normal audiences and present our work beyond our normal spaces,
places where the presenting art in places that are not places where fine arts is normally
presented as often one of the outcomes of these collaborations.
And force scientists to expand our vocabulary in communicating with quote the general public,
quote the non-professional non-science public.
So I think we need each other to fight our elitism problem.
And the good news is there's sort of a natural breaking down of those barriers that comes
when we do this transdisciplinary work of working beyond our normal professional boundaries.

All I can tell you is I understand less now than less now than less.
So whatever that's wrong.
Yes, whatever the truth is highly successful.
Highly successful.

And I think we don't want to smush everything together.
I do think there's a value to boundaries and borders.
Good fences make good neighbors and things of that nature because there are a lot of
ways to understand things.
There's paintings are away, novels are away, scientific experiments are away.
And I don't think we want to dismiss any of those ways or try and mush them all together.
What we really want is to develop a more pluralistic approach, if anything, where not only—and

I mean pluralism is, in my opinion, more than simply diversity, it's the ability to allow

They're at odds in some way or another.
But they're both important ideas.
There's a great quote of you don't mind.
When Neil's board said the opposite of a fact is a falsehood, but the opposite of a profound

And that, I think, really hard to hold in your head a little bit, but a very important

So I'm not entirely against some of the boundaries that we have with art and science.
Now, the failure to communicate or whether the elitism or things like that, I mean elitism

I'll just give the floor to Ben.
But I think we do have to be a little—this came up a little bit in the last panel, the

And so elitism grows, unfortunately, is a little bit of a weed or a lichen on expertise.
Well, we don't want to lose expertise in the fight against elitism, which I agree we could

I'm actually going to pick up on the expertise thread first, which is one thing we've learned
is—okay, so what I do now, I open an event space.
And our notion is to provide a home for what we call intelligent nightlife.
And we want a place where people can come out and have extraordinary things happen in

But more than that, when I pitch to producers, what I want is a space where we have blending
discussion of the academics with knowledge from the performing arts.
And there, it's—what is key to us is recognizing the expertise that exists in all of the domains

So for example, we bring in comedy groups and we ask them, you know, okay, you're really
great at comedy.
Can you do something that fits our space?
Can you do something that is in line with our mission of, you know, exhibiting thought
in new ways?
We're still searching for good ways of saying this.
But so we've had a couple great successes with that.
Just last night we hosted a group there called North Coast.
They're a hip-hop improv group and they improvised a musical in the style of Hamilton and it
was brilliant.
These people came in, they executed.
It was gorgeous.
A while ago we brought in another comedy group.
They run what's known as a very supportive open mic, trying to develop new comics.
And so we're like, great, we will bring them in.
We'll give them the mission of doing shows that involve science or other think-y thoughts.
And they said, yeah, yeah, great, we'll do that.
And the show had nothing to do with that whatsoever.
And there was somewhere along the line we forgot to look at what they were doing and
say, oh, this is what their expert in.
Let's work with their own expertise instead of trying to put what we want to have happen
on top of it.
Whereas with North Coast they have developed their own expertise and now our job is to
pair them with historians and people who are going to really make that sort of thing shine.
But more broadly when you're talking about elitism, and this is a lesson we're learning

disciplinary, it's not automatic and you have to do it very intentionally.
And so part of that comes from what other expertise you recognize.
If we're going out and we're working with comedy groups, are we only going out and working

And I've seen this happen, I've seen us do it.
Or are we going out and looking for groups, I have a group coming in that organizes intellectual,

It used to be called drunk TED talks but they sent him a cease and desist.
I was great by the way.
But one of the first things he said to me is that he organized one of his most successful

A lot of people in this crowd are going to look at that and say, is that really the

And the answer is if you really are serious about breaking through this barrier and not

And that can be the big challenge for really getting out and really having this discussion

Yeah, presenting in non-traditional spaces is really good for that.
And part of what I was saying before is that these collaborations often force scientists

And so just by the nature of reaching across those boundaries you find yourself in front

And that alone is I think very valuable.
So a C.D. Snow is actually the one who first brought up the idea of a neutral space and

All of our events are free and open to the public so that breaks down some barriers that

I'm sorry.
One of the things I think would not be such a bad topic to talk about for a little bit

I think the scientific revolution is probably important.
What was important for a new way of thinking?
It was important for a way of thinking that said you don't get knowledge from authority,

But especially notions of uncertainty.

Not that it's a failing, but it's crucial to good science, that you can't have science

I think one of the key things there is the lens that you view the rest of society.

I think that's a destructive way to look at what we're doing.
Yes, but the sort of lens that you use shapes how you're thinking about the activity.
So you're talking about how do we communicate ideas and so the statement is, oh, then we

To me, there's a sense in which that's mind blowing.
If you want to talk through issues of uncertainty, you could do a whole lot worse than talk to

And that is a very destructive way of doing it.
I'm agreeing with you.
It's very unclear and uncertain, as always, but it's really, this is where we need to

There are different ways to think about scientific literacy, for sure.
I think it's a good question to ask.
What do we even mean by that?
And before in the previous panel, people were talking about not liking the acronym STEAM.
I've never liked the acronym STEM, Science, Technology, Engineering, Math.
Not because I don't think it's a reasonable summation of some corner of knowledge that

We need STEM education because we need to prepare people for jobs and vocations and

There's a more profound, deeper sense of connection to the world than just, here's a way to get

That's why we need to get people into STEM careers.
So I think of science literacy as spreading a way of interrogating the world, seeing ourselves

And when you think of it that way, it's not just something that's like sort of a good

And it doesn't do any good to just have the scientists be aware of it and not really

We've learned some important things.

And so I do see that in a way science literacy, but it's not like here's the facts we know

It's not dumbing down.
